bibl.title: Letter from Laura Armistead Carter to [Frederick F. Russell], [19--]

div1.p: Laura Carter informs Russell that she left the Ravenel correspondence with Read, but did not use it because her father's book ends before Reed's yellow fever work commenced.

div1.head: Letter from Laura Armistead Carter to [Frederick F. Russell], [19--]
div1.p:
By the way, if you've had a chance to read the correspondence,
which I left with Miss Read, in connection with Dr. Mazyck Ravenel's
letter, you can see why I didn't bring it up when we were discussing
the History of Yellow Fever. Father's book ends (the historical part,
I mean) long before the triumphant demonstration of the Reed Board,
and, such being the case. I saw, and see, no reason for incorporating
any of the material referred to at the beginning of this paragraph, in
the book--the more so as Father was particularly averse thereto. I
simply took the carbon to New York because I thought you would all be
interested in it as fragment of unpublished history.

With best wishes to youaall at headquarters and to Dr. Beeuwkes
when you write, and with many happy recollections of my stay in New York,
